Analysis: the airplane was in level cruise flight on the second leg of a flight when the engine lost
power the pilot declared an emergency with air traffic control atc and requested the nearest airport
as the airplane was descending through ft mean sea level msl the atc controller told him that
there was an airport airport a at his position and about 15 nautical miles nm away
however there was another airport airport b that was about nm away that the controller did not
tell the pilot about at this time
the pilot responded that he had partial power and would see if he could make it to airport a he then
asked for and received a vector to airport a about 2 minutes later as the airplane descended through
ft msl the pilot asked the controller if there was something closer and the controller told him that
there was another airport airport b at his to position and 10 nm away the pilot requested
a turn toward airport b the controller told the pilot to turn right and proceed direct and the airplane
turned right toward airport b airport b was actually about nm away
about 2 minutes later as the airplane descended through ft msl the controller advised the pilot
that there was a private airstrip about 1 mile behind him the airstrip was actually 10 nm away the
pilot replied wish i knew where that was the controller then provided the pilot with runway
information for airport b the pilot responded where that private strip the controller responded
it not close enough for you to get to as the airplane descended through ft msl the controller
then gave the pilot his position and distance to airports a and b there were no further transmissions
from the pilot
radar data showed that the airplane made a right turn to the south about 2 minutes later the
Probable Cause and Findings: the national transportation safety board determines the probable cause s of this accident to be
the pilot failure to properly position the fuel selector which resulted in a total loss of engine
power due to fuel starvation contributing to the severity of the accident was the pilot failure
Factual Information: loss of engine power total defining event
this report was modified on please see the public docket for this accident to view the
on july 26 2015 at 1513 central daylight time a beechcraft v35b airplane n252g struck trees and
impacted terrain during a forced landing near colbert oklahoma the private pilot was fatally injured
and the passenger was seriously injured and died 5 days later the airplane was substantially damaged
the airplane was registered to avprop llc and operated by the pilot under the provisions of 14 code
of federal regulations cfr part 91 as a personal flight visual meteorological conditions prevailed at
the time of the accident and an instrument flight rules flight plan had been filed the flight originated
from national airport sgf springfield missouri at 1317
the pilot and his wife were returning to fort worth texas from jackson michigan earlier in the day
the couple departed from jackson field jxn jackson michigan and flew to sgf
where they landed and refueled taking on 45 gallons of aviation gasoline a fuel receipt showed a time
of gps data showed that the airplane took off to the and then turned southwest
toward fort worth the airplane climbed to and maintained mean seal level msl
about 1501 the pilot contacted the fort worth air traffic control center zfw and declared an
emergency reporting that the airplane had lost engine power and that he needed to get to an airport right
away as the airplane was descending through msl the zfw air traffic controller told the pilot
Pilot Information: estimated 1491 hours total all aircraft 1460 hours total this make and model hours
the pilot held a private pilot with land airplane and instrument ratings on
april 14 2015 he received a special issuance medical limited by a requirement for
corrective lenses and marked not valid for any class after
the pilot logbook showed that he had flown total hours hours of which were in the 30
days before the accident the logbook also showed that the pilot successfully completed a flight review
and instrument proficiency check in the accident airplane make and model on may 14 2015
Aircraft and Owner/Operator Information: the airplane was registered to a corporation
and used by the pilot for both business and pleasure it was equipped with two fuel tanks and
powered by a 285 horsepower continental motors
a review of the airframe and records revealed that the airplane had undergone a
inspection on january 14 2015 at an airframe time of hours
Meteorological Information and Flight Pl: at 1155 the automated weather observation station at dua located 9
northeast of the accident site recorded 190 deg at 7 10 clear
skies temperature 36 deg c dew 19 deg c and inches of
Wreckage and Impact Information: the accident site was located in a wooded area along the east side of a road about 5 miles southeast of
colbert the site was surrounded by fields suitable for a forced landing the airplane came to rest
upright and was oriented on a westerly heading the airplane initially impacted some pine
trees about 100 of the wreckage several tree branches in the immediate vicinity of the
airplane were broken and showed marks consistent with impact marks on the airplane wings and
fuselage the debris path was on a bearing of about from the initial tree impact about 40 east of
the airplane was an impact crater that measured about 25 wide and 20 long airplane debris and
dirt fanned out from the crater toward the airplane wreckage
within the debris field were pieces from the engine cowling forward fuselage windscreen and fuel
system also within the debris field were luggage and broken branches
the main wreckage consisted of the cabin fuselage engine propeller left and right wings and
empennage see figure 1 for a photograph showing the accident site and main wreckage
